metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Investigate and analyse theoretically and practically the generation of electromotive force (emf) including AC voltage and calculations using induced emf: ε = −NΔΦ_B/Δt, with reference to: rate of change of magnetic flux, number of loops through which the flux passes, direction of induced emf in a coil

faraday_formula.name: Faraday's Law Formula
faraday_formula.correct: Faraday's law states that induced EMF equals the negative of the number of turns multiplied by the rate of change of magnetic flux.

ε = NΔΦ_B/Δt.fix: The negative sign represents Lenz's law and indicates that the induced EMF opposes the change in flux.
ε = NΔΦ_B/Δt.action: Consider what would happen if the induced current supported the change - you would get unlimited energy.

ε = −ΔΦ_B/Δt.error: Missing N, the number of turns.
ε = −ΔΦ_B/Δt.fix: Each loop in a coil contributes to the total EMF. More loops means more EMF for the same flux change.
ε = −ΔΦ_B/Δt.action: A coil with 100 turns produces 100 times the EMF of a single loop.

ε = −NΦ_B/Δt.error: Using total flux instead of change in flux.
ε = −NΦ_B/Δt.fix: Only changes in magnetic flux induce EMF. Constant flux produces zero EMF.
ε = −NΦ_B/Δt.action: A stationary magnet near a coil produces no current - only moving magnets work.

persistent.gap: You are not correctly applying the complete Faraday's law equation.
persistent.action: Write out the full formula ε = −NΔΦ_B/Δt and identify what each symbol represents.

emf_definition.name: Electromotive Force
emf_definition.correct: EMF is the potential difference between terminals of a source when no current flows. It represents energy per unit charge provided by the source.

a force measured in newtons.error: Despite the name, EMF is not a force.
a force measured in newtons.fix: EMF is measured in volts (V), not newtons. It describes electrical potential, not mechanical force.
a force measured in newtons.action: The word 'force' in EMF is historical - think of it as 'electrical driving potential'.

the same as voltage drop.error: EMF is source potential, not load potential.
the same as voltage drop.fix: EMF is the potential a source provides. Voltage drop is potential lost across a component.
the same as voltage drop.action: EMF puts energy INTO the circuit; voltage drops take energy OUT.

current through a circuit.error: EMF is potential difference, not current.
current through a circuit.fix: EMF drives current but is not current itself. EMF is measured in volts, current in amperes.
current through a circuit.action: EMF is the cause; current is the effect when there is a complete circuit.

persistent.gap: You are confusing EMF with other electrical quantities.
persistent.action: Remember: EMF = energy provided per coulomb = volts. It is electrical potential, not force or current.

rate_of_change.name: Rate of Change of Flux
rate_of_change.correct: The rate of change of magnetic flux equals the change in flux divided by the time interval. Faster changes produce greater induced EMF.

total flux through coil.error: Static flux does not induce EMF.
total flux through coil.fix: Only CHANGING flux induces EMF. A constant magnetic field through a stationary coil produces zero EMF.
total flux through coil.action: Move a magnet faster into a coil - you get more EMF because the rate of flux change is greater.

flux multiplied by time.fix: Rate of change is flux DIVIDED by time, not multiplied. Shorter time for same flux change means faster rate.
flux multiplied by time.action: Rate = change ÷ time, just like speed = distance ÷ time.

number of field lines.error: That is flux magnitude, not rate of change.
number of field lines.fix: Rate of change measures how quickly the number of field lines through the coil is increasing or decreasing.
number of field lines.action: A coil entering a field quickly has a high rate of flux change; entering slowly has a low rate.

persistent.gap: You are confusing flux magnitude with rate of flux change.
persistent.action: Always ask: How much did the flux change (ΔΦ)? How long did it take (Δt)? Rate = ΔΦ/Δt.

number_of_turns.name: Number of Turns Effect
number_of_turns.correct: The induced EMF is directly proportional to the number of turns in the coil. Doubling the turns doubles the EMF.

inversely proportional to N.fix: More turns means MORE induced EMF, not less. Each loop adds to the total.
inversely proportional to N.action: Think of N loops in series - their individual EMFs add together.

proportional to N squared.error: The relationship is linear, not quadratic.
proportional to N squared.fix: EMF = N × (ΔΦ/Δt). Doubling N doubles EMF, not quadruples it.
proportional to N squared.action: Check the formula - N appears to the first power, not N².

independent of N.fix: A coil with 100 turns produces 100 times the EMF of a single loop with the same flux change.
independent of N.action: This is why generators use coils with many turns - more turns = more voltage output.

persistent.gap: You are not correctly understanding how coil turns affect induced EMF.
persistent.action: Use ε = NΔΦ/Δt and calculate EMF for N=1, N=10, N=100 with the same flux change.

lenz_law_direction.name: Lenz's Law Direction
lenz_law_direction.formula: Induced B opposes change in applied B
lenz_law_direction.correct: The induced current creates a magnetic field that opposes the CHANGE in magnetic flux that produced it. This is Lenz's law.

opposes the original magnetic field.error: Opposes the CHANGE, not the field itself.
opposes the original magnetic field.fix: If flux is increasing, induced field opposes that increase. If decreasing, induced field opposes that decrease.
opposes the original magnetic field.action: A north pole approaching creates induced north pole to repel. A north pole leaving creates induced south pole to attract.

supports the change in flux.error: This would violate conservation of energy.
supports the change in flux.fix: If induced current supported the change, flux would increase further, inducing more current, creating unlimited energy.
supports the change in flux.action: Lenz's law is nature's way of conserving energy in electromagnetic induction.

is always in the same direction.error: Direction depends on whether flux is increasing or decreasing.
is always in the same direction.fix: Induced current reverses direction when the flux change reverses - this is why AC is produced in generators.
is always in the same direction.action: Push a magnet in, current flows one way. Pull it out, current reverses.

persistent.gap: You are not correctly applying Lenz's law to determine direction.
persistent.action: Always ask: Is flux increasing or decreasing? The induced field opposes THAT change.

negative_sign_meaning.name: Negative Sign in Faraday's Law
negative_sign_meaning.correct: The negative sign indicates that the induced EMF produces a magnetic field that opposes the change in flux. This is Lenz's law expressed mathematically.

EMF is always negative.error: The sign indicates direction relative to flux change, not that EMF itself is negative.
EMF is always negative.fix: If flux increases (positive ΔΦ), EMF is negative. If flux decreases (negative ΔΦ), EMF is positive.
EMF is always negative.action: The negative sign captures the opposition between induced EMF and flux change directions.

indicates energy loss.error: It represents direction, not energy loss.
indicates energy loss.fix: The sign shows that induced current creates an opposing magnetic field, consistent with energy conservation.
indicates energy loss.action: Energy is conserved - work done moving the magnet equals electrical energy produced.

can be ignored in calculations.error: The sign is essential for determining current direction.
can be ignored in calculations.fix: While you can often calculate magnitude without the sign, direction requires applying Lenz's law.
can be ignored in calculations.action: For magnitude questions, use |ε| = N|ΔΦ/Δt|. For direction questions, apply the negative sign.

persistent.gap: You are not understanding the physical meaning of the negative sign.
persistent.action: The minus sign is Lenz's law in mathematical form - induced effects oppose changes that cause them.

flux_change_methods.name: Methods to Change Flux
flux_change_methods.correct: Magnetic flux can be changed by: changing field strength B, changing area A within the field, changing angle between B and A, or moving the coil relative to the field.

only by moving magnets.error: There are multiple ways to change flux.
only by moving magnets.fix: You can also change coil area, rotate the coil, or use an electromagnet to vary field strength.
only by moving magnets.action: Generators rotate coils; transformers vary field strength with AC current.

changing the number of turns.error: N affects EMF but not flux through each loop.
changing the number of turns.fix: Changing N changes total EMF, but the flux through each individual loop depends on B and A.
changing the number of turns.action: More turns means more voltage, but each loop still experiences the same flux change.

increasing coil resistance.error: Resistance affects current, not flux or EMF.
increasing coil resistance.fix: EMF depends only on flux change rate. Resistance determines how much current flows for that EMF.
increasing coil resistance.action: V = IR applies after EMF is induced. The EMF itself depends only on ΔΦ/Δt.

persistent.gap: You are not recognizing all the ways to change magnetic flux.
persistent.action: Remember Φ = BA. Any change to B, A, or the angle between them changes flux.

gradient_interpretation.name: Gradient of Φ-t Graph
gradient_interpretation.formula: Gradient of Φ_B vs t = ΔΦ/Δt = −ε/N
gradient_interpretation.correct: The gradient of a magnetic flux vs time graph equals the rate of change of flux. EMF magnitude equals N times the absolute value of this gradient.

area under the graph.error: Area is not related to EMF.
area under the graph.fix: Gradient (slope) gives rate of change. For EMF, you need the gradient, not the area.
area under the graph.action: Rate of change = rise/run = gradient. Steeper slope = faster flux change = more EMF.

the y-intercept.error: The y-intercept is initial flux, not rate of change.
the y-intercept.fix: Rate of change is the slope of the line, not where it crosses the axis.
the y-intercept.action: A horizontal line has zero gradient = zero rate of change = zero EMF.

total flux at that time.error: That is the y-value, not the gradient.
total flux at that time.fix: Reading the y-value gives flux magnitude. The gradient tells you how fast flux is changing.
total flux at that time.action: Calculate gradient: pick two points, find Δy/Δx = ΔΦ/Δt.

persistent.gap: You are confusing graph features with the gradient.
persistent.action: Practice calculating gradients. Gradient = rise/run = (Φ₂ - Φ₁)/(t₂ - t₁).

right_hand_coil_rule.name: Right-Hand Coil Rule
right_hand_coil_rule.formula: Thumb = induced B direction, fingers = current direction
right_hand_coil_rule.correct: When fingers curl in the direction of current flow around a coil, the thumb points in the direction of the magnetic field inside the coil.

thumb points to current direction.fix: For coils: fingers = current direction, thumb = field direction. This is opposite to the straight wire rule.
thumb points to current direction.action: Curl fingers around coil following current; thumb points along coil axis showing B direction.

only works for solenoids.error: Works for any current loop or coil.
only works for solenoids.fix: The rule applies to single loops, multi-turn coils, and solenoids - any circular current path.
only works for solenoids.action: A single loop is just a coil with N = 1.

gives electric field direction.error: This rule is for magnetic fields.
gives electric field direction.fix: The right-hand coil rule determines magnetic field direction from current direction in loops.
gives electric field direction.action: Electric fields point from positive to negative; magnetic fields circulate around currents.

persistent.gap: You are not correctly applying the right-hand coil rule.
persistent.action: Practice: identify current direction, curl fingers that way around coil, thumb shows B inside coil.

emf_current_relationship.name: EMF and Current Relationship
emf_current_relationship.correct: Induced EMF exists whether or not current flows. Current only flows if there is a complete circuit, and is determined by EMF and total resistance.

no EMF without current.error: EMF exists even in open circuits.
no EMF without current.fix: EMF is induced whenever flux changes. An open circuit still has EMF but zero current.
no EMF without current.action: A voltmeter across an open coil measures EMF; ammeter reads zero because circuit is incomplete.

current creates the EMF.fix: Changing magnetic flux induces EMF. If there is a complete circuit, this EMF then drives current.
current creates the EMF.action: Flux change → EMF → current (if circuit complete). EMF is the cause, current is the effect.

current is always proportional to flux.error: Current depends on EMF and resistance.
current is always proportional to flux.fix: I = ε/R. Current depends on rate of flux change (through ε) AND circuit resistance.
current is always proportional to flux.action: Same flux change in high-resistance circuit produces less current than low-resistance circuit.

persistent.gap: You are confusing the relationship between EMF, current, and flux change.
persistent.action: Chain of causation: ΔΦ/Δt → ε (always), then ε/R → I (only if circuit complete).

conservation_energy_induction.name: Energy Conservation in Induction
conservation_energy_induction.correct: The work done pushing a magnet into a coil against the repulsive force equals the electrical energy induced. This is why Lenz's law must hold.

energy is created from nothing.fix: Mechanical work done moving the magnet is converted to electrical energy. Energy is transformed, not created.
energy is created from nothing.action: If you feel resistance pushing a magnet into a coil, you are doing work that becomes electrical energy.

the magnet loses magnetic energy.error: Permanent magnets do not lose magnetism during induction.
the magnet loses magnetic energy.fix: The energy comes from the mechanical work done moving the magnet, not from the magnet itself.
the magnet loses magnetic energy.action: You have to keep pushing - the magnet does not get weaker.

induced current supplies extra energy.error: Induced current is the result, not the source of energy.
induced current supplies extra energy.fix: The induced current's magnetic field creates resistance to motion. This ensures energy input = energy output.
induced current supplies extra energy.action: Lenz's law guarantees you cannot get more electrical energy out than mechanical energy you put in.

persistent.gap: You are not understanding energy conservation in electromagnetic induction.
persistent.action: Trace the energy: your arm → kinetic energy of magnet → work against Lenz force → electrical energy.
